details.title: Commentary: the Khamis/Higgins model

p: Haiyan Xu received the B.S. in 1999 in Mathematics and the M.S. in 2002 in Statistics from Shanghai Teachers' University. She is a graduate student pursuing her Ph.D. Degree at Shanghai Teachers' University. Her research interests include applied statistics and reliability.

Yincai Tang is an Associate Professor at Shanghai Teachers' University where he has been teaching Statistics since 1992. He received the M.S. in Applied Mathematics from Shanghai Teachers' University, and the Ph.D. in 1999 from East China Normal University. His research interests are life testing, reliability theory, and empirical finance.

details.abstract: This paper shows that the 'KH model' proposed by Khamis & Higgins (see ibid., vol.47, p.131-4, 1998) is not a new model but is a special case of the multiple step-stress TFR model for Weibull distributions.

references.title: Optimum simple step-stress accelerated life tests

context.text: Nelson [8] provided an extensive and comprehensive source for theory and examples for ALT, while Bai [1], Kim & Li, Bai & Kim [2] further studied optimum simple SS-ALT.

links.abstract: The authors present the optimum simple time-step and failure-step stress accelerated life tests for the case where a prespecified censoring time is involved. An exponential life distribution with a mean that is a log-linear function of stress, and a cumulative exposure model are assumed. The authors obtain the optimum test plans to minimize the asymptotic variance of the maximum-likelihood estimator of the mean life at a design stress. Nomographs for the optimum time-step stress test are also gi...

references.text: D. S. Bai, M. S. Kim, S. H. Lee, "Optimum simple step-stress accelerated life tests", IEEE Trans. Rel., vol. 38, pp. 528-532, 1989.

references.title: A tampered failure rate model for step-stress accelerated life test

context.text: It is different from CE model, but it is not different from the TFR model. [5] only noticed the 2-step TFR model [3] but not the multiple step-stress TFR model, a general model studied by Madi [6] based on the conclusions of Bahttacharyya & Soejoeti [3].
The TFR model was first proposed by Bhattacharrya & Soejoeti [3] and then generalized by Madi [6].

references.text: G. K. Bhattacharrya, Z. Soejoeti, "A tampered failure rate model for step-stress accelerated life test", Communications in Statistics Theory and Methods, vol. 18, pp. 1627-1643.

references.title: Bayesian estimation and optimal design in partially accelerated life-testing
references.text: M. H. Degroot, P. K. Goel, "Bayesian estimation and optimal design in partially accelerated life-testing", Nav. Res. Logist. Quarter., vol. 26, pp. 223-235, 1979.

references.title: A new model for step-stress testing

context.text: For the \$k\$-step SS-ALT, Khamis & Higgins [5]22Some errors in that article occur in obtaining the Maximum Likelihood Estimator and the Fisher Information Matrix. proposes a so called KH model for Weibull distributions, based on a time transformation of the exponential CE model.
[5] only noticed the 2-step TFR model [3] but not the multiple step-stress TFR model, a general model studied by Madi [6] based on the conclusions of Bahttacharyya & Soejoeti [3].
Reference [5]proposes the KH model with assumptions #1–4.
To show no difference with [5], one need only consider that \$\tau _{c} is \infty \$.

links.abstract: The mathematical intractability of the Weibull cumulative exposure model (CE-M) has impeded the development of statistical procedures for step-stress accelerated life tests. Our new model (KH-M) is based on a time transformation of the exponential CE-M. The time-transformation enables the reliability engineer to use known results for multiple-step, multiple-stress models that have been developed for the exponential step-stress model. KH-M has a realistically appealing proportional-hazard propert...

references.text: I. H. Khamis, S. H. Higgins, "A new model for step-stress testing", IEEE Trans. Rel., vol. 47, pp. 131-134, 1998.

references.title: Multiple step-stress accelerated life test: The tampered failure rate model

context.text: It is different from CE model, but it is not different from the TFR model. [5] only noticed the 2-step TFR model [3] but not the multiple step-stress TFR model, a general model studied by Madi [6] based on the conclusions of Bahttacharyya & Soejoeti [3].
The TFR model was first proposed by Bhattacharrya & Soejoeti [3] and then generalized by Madi [6].
The factor used here is different from the “tampered factor” used by Madi [6].

references.text: M. T. Madi, "Multiple step-stress accelerated life test: The tampered failure rate model", Communications in Statistics Theory and Methods, vol. 22, pp. 2631-2639.

references.title: Accelerated life testing&#821Step-stress models and data analysis

links.abstract: This paper presents statistical models and methods for analyzing accelerated life-test data from step-stress tests. Maximum likelihood methods provide estimates of the parameters of such models, the life distribution under constant stress, and other information. While the methods are applied to the Weibull distribution and inverse power law, they apply to many other accelerated life test models. These methods are illustrated with step-stress data on time to breakdown of an electrical insulation.

references.text: W. B. Nelson, "Accelerated life testing̵Step-stress models and data analysis", IEEE Trans. Rel., vol. R-29, pp. 103-108, 1980.
